comment: Speyside Scotch notes and flavor - albeit, on a very watered-down level.  Light on the pocketbook, but want some Scotch... well, this may be your ticket.  Won’t blow your mind, but it also won’t blow you wad.
light on all flavors, slightly Woody and sweet raisins with a hint of honey, add a little bit of water or ice and palate opens up to enjoy it while sipping away, a typical speyside
Good tasting, smooth inexpensive Scotch. A good everyday drinker.
No age stated on the bottle.  Single malt that has a decent taste.  Price wise $20 or less for a single malt that tastes like a single malt from a Speyside distillery.
Smell sweet peanuts and toffee. Taste like I added water even though I haven't. Buttery like an irish but with very little smoke on the end.
Has more of a bite, on the cheaper end of the single malts. Balanced flavor
A bargain! $27 gets you a pleasant easy drinkng speyside malt that’s not gonna offend anyone. It’s not complex or outstanding, just a solid scotch.

This is my first Scotch EVER! I enjoyed this gift and am excited to learn more about scotch. This had a bit of a fruity overtones (I tasted pear/apricot) with a smoky/earthy aftertaste (barrel? peat?). Very fun!
yeasty bread on the nose. makes the taste a little off.
Good flavor for the money. Go-to budget option.
Earl grey, cedar, spice and cardamom.

I am a fan of Glenn Moray and this was the closest I found at Trader Joe’s.   The nut and Carmel come out to play over ice!  It’s a easy Happy hour sipping scotch or night cap pleasure. Not extravagant but simple joy!
a slight peat with earthy tones. a bit of water brought out the earth and a bit of ash.
A bit sweet and light, but still produces a nice peat note in the back.
Nose is peanut brittle with mild peat and smoke.  Taste has some honey notes and similar peat/smoke from the nose.  Almost seems slightly watered down even though I added no water.
Sweet, honey, with slight fruit flavors. Overall light Scotch.
